questions.text: Epithelial mesenchymal transmission induced by which pair of transcription factors?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SNAIL & TWIST Epithelial Mesenchymal Transmission is controlled by the transcription factors SNAIL and TWIST and is defined not only by the downregulation of epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) but also by the concomitant upregulation of mesenchymal markers

Highyeild:

Epithelial Mesenchymal Transmission is controlled by the transcription factors SNAIL and TWIST and is defined not only by the downregulation of epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) but also by the concomitant upregulation of mesenchymal markers Metastasis oncogenes: SNAIL & TWIST: encode transcription factors which promote epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) EMT: Down-regulation of epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) and up-regulation of mesenchymal markers (e.g., vimentin and smooth muscle actin) Pro-migratory phenotype is essential for metastasis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B and D. These are incorrect options and does not leads to epithelial mesenchymal transmission

questions.text: A patient presents with a lesion on the hand. Histopathology of the lesion is given. Which of the following is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Verocay bodies are seen in light microscopy

options.label: D
options.text: The given is malignant and metastasize frequently

questions.correct_answer: D. The given is malignant and metastasize frequently
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The given is malignant and metastasize frequently The given is malignant and metastasize frequently with Histopathological images shows pseudo stratification of spindle curved shaped nuclei with blunt end is suggestive of Schwannoma and its a benign tumor dont transform to malignant and dont metastatizes.

Highyeild:

Features Schwannomas Neurofibromas General characteristics ● Benign tumors ● Arise directly from peripheral nerves Q • Benign tumors • Heterogeneous in composition. • The neoplastic Schwann cells admixed with perineurial like cells, fibroblasts, mast cells, and CD34+ spindle cells Q Gross Well-circumscribed, encapsulated Non-encapsulated mass Q Morphology Antoni A-cellular areas • Antoni B- loose edematous areas • Verocay bodies Q foci of palisaded nuclei in cellular areas 3 types of neurofibroma are there: Localized ● Low cellularity Q Diffuse • Diffusely infiltrates the dermis giving plaque-like appearance Q •Pseudo-Meissner corpuscles or tactile-like bodies Plexiform • These tumors grow within and expand nerve fascicles. • Bag of worms" Q appearance • CARROT SHAVINGS Genetics Loss of NF2 gene product, merlin Loss of the NF1 gene product, neurofibromin Malignant transformation Extremely rare Occur especially in plexiform neurofibroma

questions.text: A young child presents with bleeding gums and bruising since two weeks. Bone marrow biopsy and flow cytometry were done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ALL: B Phenotype Peripheral smear shows mainly lymphoblast having very scant cytoplasm, and positivity for CD 10 and CD 10 is suggestive of ALL B phenotype

Highyeild:

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) Definition: Neoplasms of immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells which are referred to as lymphoblasts Epidemiology: ALL is the most common cancer of children Q , Peak Incidence: 3rd yr Q Hispanics have the highest incidence of any ethnic group. Pathogenesis: OT-ALLs have gain-of-function mutations in NOTCH19 Q B-ALLs have loss-of-function mutations PAX5 Q , E2A Q & EBF Q , or t(12;21) Q involving the genes ETV6 and RUNX1, 2 genes that are needed in very early hematopoietic precursor. Clinical features: Abrupt stormy onset Symptoms related to depression of marrow function: Fatigue due to anemia; Fever due to neutropenia; and Bleeding due to thrombocytopenia Marrow expansion and infiltration of the sub- periosteum: sternal tenderness Q Generalized lymphadenopathy, Hepatosplenomegaly; testicular enlargement OT-ALL: Mediastinal mass (Superior Mediastinal Syndrome) Q CNS features: headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies Morphology: Hypercellular Bone Marrow; > 20% lymphoblasts Q Compared with myeloblasts, lymphoblasts have more condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli & scanty agranular cytoplasm Cytochemistry: Myeloperoxidase (MPO) -ve, Sudan Black B (SBB): -ve Q Diagnosis of choice Flow cytometry Lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphomas (ALL)- (TdT+) B-ALL MARKERS T-ALL MARKERS B-cell precursor CD19+ and/or cCD79a+ and/ or cCD22+ T-cell precursor Cytoplasmic CD3+, CD7+ Pro-B-ALL No expression of other B-cell markers Pro-T-ALL No expression of other T-cell markers Common- ALL CD10+, cytoplasmic µ-) Pre-T-ALL CD2+ and/or CD5+ Pre-B-ALL Cytoplasmic μ + Cortical T-ALL Mature T-ALL CD1a+ Membrane CD3+

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . These atypical cells have very scant cytoplasm and 2-4 nucleoli with granules in the cytoplasm and aure rod Option: B. This will show These are small, well-differentiated, normal-appearing lymphocytes with smudge cells characteristic of chronic lymphocytic leukemia, the most common leukemia or lymphoma in adults. Option: D. Already explained above

questions.text: Identify the structure on prostate biopsy:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Corpora amylacea The glands are lined by two layers of cells: a basal layer of low cuboidal basal epithelium covered by a layer of columnar secretory cells and contains secretion in lumen is called as Corpora amylacea

Highyeild:

Histology of prostate: Glandular regions The prostate has three main glandular regions: the central zone, the peripheral zone, and the transition zone. Each zone has its own architectural and stromal features. Stroma The prostate's stroma is fibromuscular, meaning it contains smooth muscle cells, fibroblasts, blood vessels, and nerves. The stroma surrounds the glandular tissue, or parenchyma. Epithelial lining The ducts and acini of the prostate are lined with secretory epithelium. The glandular epithelium is mostly simple columnar and cuboidal epithelial cells, but may also have regions of pseudostratified columnar epithelium. Basal cells A layer of basal cells is present beneath the secretory lining in each zone. These are small, round stem cells that rest on the basement membrane. Prostatic concretions (corpora amylacea) These are precipitations of prostatic glandular secretions that can be found in the lumen of prostatic glands. They are more common in older men and increase in number and size with age.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Keratin will be flake like and is eosinophilic to grey in color Option: B. Single necrotic cells may constitute seed crystals that become encrusted by the mineral deposits. The progressive acquisition of outer layers may create lamellated configurations, called psammoma bodies. Seen in papillary cancers Option: D. This will be extracellular and homogenous acellular eosinophilic deposition

Speckled Fine or coarse, usually without staining of the nucleoli SS-A SS-B Sm RNP + others High titres: Sjogrens- Sicca syndrome complex SLE MCTD Scleroderma Low titres: Miscl conn. Tissue dis. Nucleolar Large coarse speckles (usually less than 6 per nucleus, with or without fine speckles) Pm-Scl Nucleolin Ku And other nuclear antigens Scleroderma; Sjogren's syndrome Centromere Discrete speckles (usually in multiples of 46) Chromosomal centromere CREST Syndrome Mitochondrial Coarse granular filamentous cytoplasmic speckled pattern extending around the nucleus and throughout the cytoplasm M2 Primary biliary cirrhosis; Scleroderma Jo-1 Fine speckled staining concentrated around the nucleus Histyl-tRNA synthetase Polymyositis; dermatomyositis associated with interstitial pulmonary disease

questions.text: While collecting a blood sample for Serum Calcium, which is easily alterable. Which of the following should be prevented to measure it accurately? If a tourniquet is needed, tie and release as soon as sample is collected Collecting after exercise Making a fist is not recommended Staying immobilised for long periods of time increases calcium levels Vacutainer containing citrate can be used Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3,4 All of the options are true except citrate vacutainer used, normally yellow toped vacutainer is used

Highyeild:

Pre-analytical factors that can affect serum calcium sample collection include: Patient posture Standing up from a supine position can increase serum calcium levels by 0.05 to 0.20 mmol/L. Venous occlusion During venipuncture, occluding the arm can increase serum calcium levels by up to 0.3 mmol/L. Hemolysis Some methods for measuring calcium are affected by high levels of hemoglobin. If a tourniquet is needed, tie and release as soon as sample is collected Syringe filling Errors can occur if the syringe is not filled to its nominal volume, especially for small specimens. Sample handling Errors can occur if the sample is contaminated, hemolyzed, or inappropriately mixed. Dietary intake : Ionized calcium levels can decrease by about 5% within 2 hours of eating. Physical activity : Moderate-intensity physical activity can increase ionized calcium levels. Circadian rhythm : Ionized calcium dosage is strongly associated with circadian rhythm. pH : pH levels can affect ionized calcium levels by impacting how it complexes with proteins and other anions.

questions.text: What is the mutation seen in Sickle cell anemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glu ---> Val (6) It’s a missense point mutation there is substitution of glutamic acid by valine in the 6th position, the beta globin chain of hemoglobin. It alters the solubility or stability of the hemoglobin and produces hemolytic anemia.

Highyeild:

Sickle Cell Anemia Defect: Point mutation in 6th codon of β-globin Q → replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue. Q Production of HbS with abnormal physiochemical properties that promotes the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin. Pathogenesis: HbS on deoxygenation forms long polymers ↓ Needle like polymers cause RBC membrane damage ↓ Initially, reversible sickling → Vaso-occlusive spasms & microvascular obstruction→ ischemic tissue damage ↓ Influx of Ca2+ ions induces cross-linking of membrane proteins & permits efflux of K* & H₂O Further membrane damage & RBC distortion ↓ Irreversible sickling ↓ Hemolysis in reticuloendothelial cells (extravascular hemolysis)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C and D. These are incorrect options

questions.text: Most common cause of inherited coagulopathy:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factor 5 Leiden mutation In the inherited causes of hypercoagulability, point mutations in the factor V gene are the most common, followed by mutation in prothrombin gene

Highyeild:

Major causes of hypercoagulable state Primary (Genetic) Common ● Factor V mutation: factor V Leiden (Arg to Gin substitution in amino acid residue 506 leading to resistance to activated protein C) ● Prothrombin mutation (G20210A noncoding sequence variant leading to increased prothrombin levels) ● Increased levels of factors VIII, IX, XI, or fibrinogen (genetics unknown) Rare ● Antithrombin III deficiency ● Protein C deficiency ● Protein S deficiency Very Rare ● Fibrinolysis defects ● Homozygous homocystinuria (deficiency of cystathionine B-synthetase) Secondary (Acquired) Strong Risk Factors for Thrombosis ● Prolonged bed rest or immobilization ● Myocardial infarction ● Atrial fibrillation ● Tissue injury (surgery, fracture, burn) ● Cancer ● Prosthetic cardiac valves ● Disseminated intravascular coagulation ● Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia ● Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome Other Risk Factors for Thrombosis ● Cardiomyopathy ● Nephrotic syndrome ● Hyperestrogenic states (pregnancy and postpartum) ● Oral contraceptive use ● Sickle cell anemia ● Smoking

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C and D. Already explained above

questions.text: Match the Following disease with their respective gene mutation: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-iii, B-i, C-iv, D-ii Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes, while familial adenomatous polyposis by APC gene mutation. Juvenile by SMAD4 and Peutz Jeghers syndrome by STK11

Highyeild:

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis: Definition: Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant inherited syndrome characterized by hundreds to thousands of adenomas throughout the colorectum as well as numerous extracolonic manifestations. Genetic features: It is caused by germ-line inactivation (5q) mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene. Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes

questions.correct_answer: D. HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11 Celiac disease shows positive serology for IgA transglutamine and IgG antigliadin. Marsh grading is done on biopsy. Celiac disease is not associated with HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11

Highyeild:

Celiac disease Fundamental disorder is sensitivity to gluten Q Gluten is protein component (gliadin) of wheat Q related grains (Oat, barley & rye). Q Hallmark: T-cell mediated chronic inflammatory reaction Q with an autoimmune component Almost all individuals share HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 Q The epithelial cells secrete excess IL-5 that activates CD8+ T cells & increases the risk of lymphoma Q Clinical Features: Classic presentation includes diarrhea, flatulence, weight loss and fatigue Q Associations: Dermatitis herpetiformis, Q Auto immune diseases, Downs & Turner syndrome, IgA, nephropathy Dramatic improvement in features of malabsorption after withdrawal of gluten Q containing substances from diet On long term, increased risk of malignancy Q - enteropa- thy-associated T-cell lymphoma Q > Small intestinal adeno- carcinoma Histological features: Biopsy specimens taken from the second portion of the duodenum or proximal jejunum are diagnostic and Marsh grading is done on biopsy Intraepithelial lymphocytosis: An increased number of intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) in the small intestine Crypt hyperplasia : An extension of the regenerative epithelial crypts Villous atrophy : A decrease in the height of the intestinal villi, which can lead to the complete disappearance of villi. Lamina propria inflammation : A chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate in the lamina propria (overall mucosa thickness remains the same) Serology of Celiac disease: Latent celiac disease-in which positive serology is not accompanied by villous atrophy Most sensitive tests are the measurement of IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase (tTG) or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin peptide (DGP) Q Specific test but not sensitive-IgA anti-endomysial antibodies

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B and C. Already explained above
